stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the Freezie enemy in the Ice Castle (Course 13), focusing on its attack animation and particle effects. He also debugs a lighting bug in the Oil Factory (Course 11) and discusses broader design topics, including a potential nerf to the dive mechanic and the game's expanding total star count.

development_findings.summary: A new 'spline light' feature has been implemented, allowing a light source to follow a defined path. The idea for the light effect to move with the platform came from Biobak.
development_findings.quote: I invented the spline light. You see how there's light coming from the spline here? Isn't that fucking sick?

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering multiple approaches to difficulty, including a 'sightseeing mode' that alters physics, but he prefers an integrated design where players can choose between safe and risky paths within the levels themselves.
development_findings.quote: I want the game to not be difficult. I want it to be like pick your own difficulty where you can go for risky jumps and like do the difficult thing or you can do the easy thing whenever you want.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is debating nerfing the ground-pound dive after a discussion with another game designer who argued it undermines the commitment of Mario 64's jumps. The proposed nerf would limit the ability to change direction mid-dive.
development_findings.quote: The logic goes through the dive you are kinda making a lot of level design trivial and also not really having many benefits from it because bad players aren't really gonna use it.

development_findings.summary: The planned star count has increased to around 180. This includes ~130 main stars, plus new mission types inspired by Super Mario Galaxy's 'Comets' and Sonic Adventure's 'Emerald Hunts'.
development_findings.quote: Dude, you know what's fucking sick? The Emerald Hunts in Sonic Adventure 1. That should just be a thing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is developing the Freezie enemy for the ice level, working on its inhale/exhale attack animations and particle effects. He reused and adapted code from the T-Rex enemy for the particle behavior.
Kaze is designing how Mario is affected by the Freezie's attack, deciding to freeze Mario in place but keep his eyes blinking for a comedic, cartoonish effect.
The game is currently in development of Course 13 out of 15, but Kaze estimates it will still be about two years from completion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife Zeina are expecting their first child, a daughter named Reyna, in approximately four weeks. Kaze plans to stream more during his upcoming parental leave.
context_findings.quote: My daughter will be born in four weeks, that's true, in four weeks I will have a child. That means I get time off and I will likely stream a little more.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses extreme paranoia about Nintendo, believing they are actively hostile towards him and might try to entrap him. He states they have previously taken down 70 of his videos.
context_findings.quote: If Nintendo ever sent me like a job offer or something or invited me to like present the game in Japan, I would think it's a ploy to like get me arrested or like to find me and kill me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's philosophy on his video editing style is that its 'bare-bones' quality is not an intentional aesthetic but a natural result of his process. He is considering hiring a video editor to increase his YouTube output.
context_findings.quote: I didn't try to make it look shitty and grassroots. It just is what it is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze articulates his game design philosophy, prioritizing challenges that are enjoyable to execute over arbitrary difficulty.
context_findings.quote: Don't make things difficult to make them difficult. Instead think about jumps that feel cool to pull off and if you need to make something difficult then just put one of those jumps that feels cool in there.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses anxiety about having a daughter, particularly regarding teaching her internet and real-life safety due to the presence of predators.
Kaze discusses his personal views on whether differences in gaming tastes between men and women are biological or societal, concluding it's likely a mix of both.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested the idea for the light dots on a platform to move in sync with the platform's movement in the oil factory level.
Biobak suggested getting custom hats with initials for Zeina and their upcoming daughter, Reyna.
biobak.quote: We should get a captain just as a Z on it for Zeina and an R for Reyna.

biobak.summary: Engaged in a discussion with Kaze about the societal versus biological reasons for gender differences in gaming preferences.

zeina.summary: Zeina joined the stream to explain that their daughter will be named Reyna in memory of a childhood friend of Kaze's who passed away.
zeina.quote: The name behind Reyna is that she's named after a friend of mine that passed away when I was 12 years old.

zeina.summary: Kaze revealed that the profile picture for his 'Kaze Clips' channel was made by Zeina.
Kaze mentioned that he and Zeina often use the combined name 'KaZeina' when playing video games together.

key_stories.title: The Dive Mechanic Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze grapples with external feedback that the game's powerful dive mechanic undermines core platforming challenges. He proposes a nerfed version to his community, sparking a debate between maintaining the 'fun feel' of the move and preserving design integrity.
key_stories.challenge: A fellow game designer argued that Mario 64's dive mechanic is 'antithetical' to the game's core design of committed jumps, as it makes platforming challenges trivial for skilled players.
key_stories.process: Kaze presented the argument to his stream, proposed a nerfed version of the dive that heavily reduces directional influence, and solicited community feedback to gauge player reactions to the potential change.
key_stories.outcome: The decision is unresolved. Kaze is weighing the fun of the powerful dive against the design principle of maintaining challenge, and is considering a 'nerfed' version with less directional control as a compromise.
key_stories.key_quote: I was thinking maybe a better way to handle the dive, which because I agree it feels really good, is you can't really change your angle with it anymore.

key_stories.title: Star Count Inflation
key_stories.summary: Kaze's plan for the game's total star count evolves live on stream. He spontaneously decides to add a new mission type inspired by Sonic Adventure, leading to an increase to ~180 stars and revealing his iterative, inspiration-driven approach to content design.
key_stories.challenge: Determining the final amount of content and star types for the game, particularly for post-game or bonus objectives, without the content feeling like filler.
key_stories.process: Kaze began with a base of 130 stars, then layered on ideas for overworld stars and 'Comet'-style missions. During the stream, he was inspired to add a new mission type based on Sonic Adventure and immediately began re-evaluating his existing list of bonus star ideas.
key_stories.outcome: The planned star count has inflated to around 180, incorporating new mission types. Kaze decided on the spot to add Sonic-style treasure hunts and began curating a list of other 'Yoshi missions' to ensure they were fun and not 'cringe'.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, you know what's fucking sick? The Emerald Hunts in Sonic Adventure 1. That should just be a thing.

key_stories.title: The Story of Reyna's Name
key_stories.summary: In a personal moment, Kaze and his wife Zeina share the emotional origin of their daughter's name. Zeina joins the stream to explain that 'Reyna' is an homage to a childhood friend of Kaze's who passed away, offering a rare glimpse into their personal lives.
key_stories.challenge: Explaining the personal significance of their unborn daughter's name to the community.
key_stories.process: Kaze brought his wife, Zeina, onto the stream via voice call. Zeina then directly shared the story that Reyna is named in homage to a childhood friend of Kaze's who passed away tragically.
key_stories.outcome: The community learned the poignant story behind the name, creating a moment of personal connection and revealing the deep meaning behind the family's choice.
key_stories.key_quote: Reyna is named after a friend of mine that passed away when I was 12 years old. She passed away two years on her 12th birthday.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a 'different game designer' gave him feedback that the dive mechanic is antithetical to Mario 64's design, which prompted him to consider a significant change.
